titleStmt.title: Deriving three-way decisions from intuitionistic fuzzy decision-theoretic rough sets

affiliation.orgName: University of Electronic Science and Technology of China

analytic.title: Deriving three-way decisions from intuitionistic fuzzy decision-theoretic rough sets

biblStruct.note: Received 4 May 2014 Received in revised form 9 December 2014 Accepted 12 December 2014

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Three-way decisions Intuitionistic fuzzy sets Loss function Decision-theoretic rough sets Multi-period decision making

div.p: Three-way decisions with decision-theoretic rough sets (DTRSs) provide a new methodology to confront risk decision problems. The risk is associated with the loss function of DTRSs. Under the intuitionistic fuzzy environment, we combine the loss functions of DTRSs with intuitionistic fuzzy sets (IFSs). Considering the new evaluation format of loss function with intuitionistic fuzzy numbers (IFNs), we propose a naive model of intuitionistic fuzzy decision-theoretic rough sets (IFDTRSs) and elaborate its relevant properties in advance. At this point, a critical issue is the determination of three-way decisions. In the frame of IFDTRSs, we then explore deriving three-way decisions for single-period decision making. Based on the positive and negative characteristics of IFNs, we design three strategies to address IFNs and derive corresponding three-way decisions. Meanwhile, we compare the three strategies and summarize their own applicabilities. In order to accommodate multi-period scenarios, we further extend IFDTRSs to the multi-period situation. With the aid of the results of the single period decision making, we analyze three aggregation operations of IFDTRSs for multi-period information, which are DIFWA, DIFPA and DIFOA, respectively. By comparing these operations, an algorithm for deriving three-way decisions in multi-period decision making is designed. These results help us to make a reasonable decision in the intuitionistic fuzzy environment. Finally, an example is presented to elaborate on three-way decisions with IFDTRSs.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Three-way decisions, consisting of acceptance, non-commitment (or further investigation) and rejection, are commonly encountered in problem solving strategies [57], such as investment decision [21,25], information filtering [14], text classification [16], risk decision [17,21], cluster analysis [23,59], government decision [28], web-based support systems [50], etc. The notion of three-way decisions is initially developed in the framework of rough sets [10,33]. More specifically, considering three pairwise disjoint regions of rough sets (i.e., positive region POSðCÞ, boundary region BNDðCÞ and negative region NEGðCÞ), Yao [53][54][55] proposed three-way decisions with the aid of the risk decision semantics. The three-way decisions comprise positive rules, boundary rules and negative rules [53,54,56,57]. The positive rules associated with the positive region produce acceptance decisions. The negative rules coming with the negative region give rise to rejection decisions, while the boundary rules (coming with the boundary region) result in decisions of non-commitment. In connection with the three basic elements of three-way decisions, Hu [10] systematically discussed three-way decisions space and three-way decisions. As an extended model of rough sets, decision-theoretic rough sets (DTRSs) vastly push the development of threeway decisions [31,37,51,56,57]. In light of Bayesian decision procedure, DTRSs were proposed by Yao et al. [51,52]. The model involves practical decision semantics and considers relevant risks. Three-way decisions with DTRSs are derived from the minimum of the overall risk.

For three-way decisions with DTRSs, Liu et al. [30] summarized the existing literatures and classified these researches in detail. Azam and Yao [2] investigated the use of game-theoretic rough set (GTRS) model in exploring the relationship between the changes of probabilistic thresholds and their impacts on uncertainty levels of different regions. Deng and Yao [7] presented an information-theoretic approach to the interpretation and determination of probabilistic thresholds. Considering the costs of misclassification, Greco et al. [9] proposed a new dominance-based rough set approach based on DTRSs. In the viewpoint of the optimization, Jia et al. [12,13] discussed the determination of the thresholds and the reduction technology for DTRSs. In light of different attitudes of decision makers, Li and Zhou [17] discussed the relationships of loss functions and proposed a multi-view DTRS decision model. Considering both the misclassification cost and test cost, Li et al. [18] designed an algorithm for attribute reduction with the minimum total cost. In the context of DTRSs, Li et al. [19] verified its non-monotonic feature of attribute reduction and designed a corresponding algorithm. Based on the DTRS model, Lingras et al. [23] redefined a loss function and proposed a cluster quality index for rough clusters. With respect to an investment decision-making, Liu et al. [25] proposed a profit-based three-way approach with DTRSs. By analyzing the different combinations of loss functions, Liu et al. [26] proposed four-level probabilistic rules choosing criteria. In addition, Liu et al. [26] also listed some methods for estimating the loss function. Min and Zhu [32] studied the attribute reduction of data with error ranges and test costs. Through combining DTRSs and granular structures, Qian et al. [36] developed a multigranulation decision-theoretic rough set. With respect to multiple sets of decision preferences, Yang and Yao [49] discussed some aggregations of loss functions in a multi-agent DTRS model. Yao [53] employed relative values between loss functions to express the thresholds and reduced the estimation amount. In light of the loss function of DTRSs, Yu et al. [59] constructed a new clustering validity evaluation function. Zhang and Miao [61] established a fundamental reduction framework for two-category DTRSs. Under a multi-class environment, Zhou [62] provided a new formulation of multi-class DTRSs. With the aforementioned literatures, the determination of loss function of DTRSs is a pivotal issue. Nowadays, some uncertain evaluation scenarios enrich the determination of loss function and make it adapt to a certain decision making environment. For example, Liang et al. [20], Liang and Liu [21,22] and Liu et al. [27] effectively estimated the loss functions in the format of triangular fuzzy numbers, hesitant fuzzy sets, intervals, and typical stochastic functions. These works extend the range of applications of three-way decision with DTRSs.

Inspired by the researches reported in [20][21][22]27], intuitionistic fuzzy sets (IFSs) proposed by Atanassov [1], are also a significant evaluation format to describe the uncertainty. Unlike an ordinary fuzzy set [8,34,60], the concept of IFSs is a more flexible way to capture the uncertainty and has a duality property, which is characterized both by a membership degree and by a non-membership degree [3]. IFSs have been witnessed in numerous situations and mainly utilize intuitionistic fuzzy numbers (IFNs) to support the decisions [3][4][5]11,15,24,[38][39][40][41][42][44][45][46][47][48]. For instance, Boran and Akay [3] proposed a new general type of similarity measure of IFSs and applied it to pattern recognition. Chaira and Ray [4] used IFSs for solving image edge detection. Based on the degrees of membership and non-membership of IFSs, Chen [5] elucidated the positive and negative evaluation effects (or optimism and pessimism) and developed a unipolar bivariate approach. Considering a combination of multigranulation rough sets with intuitionistic fuzzy rough sets, Huang et al. [11] developed a new multigranulation rough set model. Vlachos and Sergiadis [38] presented an information-theoretic approach to discrimination measures for IFNs and wielded it in the context of pattern recognition. In the field of multi-criteria decision making, Li [15], Liu and Wang [24], Xu [40] and Yager [47] discussed some aggregation operations of IFNs with different contexts. Unlike the existing works presented in [20][21][22]27], this paper introduces the IFN into DTRSs and proposes a new model of intuitionistic fuzzy decisiontheoretic rough sets (IFDTRSs). By utilizing the positive and negative characteristic of IFNs [5], we design three strategies to address IFNs and deduce appropriate three-way decisions. In addition, there also exist some multi-period scenarios in real decision making procedure, e.g., multi-period (multi-stage) investment decision making, medical diagnosis, personnel dynamic examination, and military system efficiency dynamic evaluation [10,43,44]. In order to accommodate multi-period scenarios [29,43,55,58], we further extend IFDTRSs with the single period decision making to the multi-period situation. With the aid of the results of the single period decision making, we analyze the determination for the aggregation of the loss function by comparing three typical operations and then design a corresponding algorithm for deriving three-way decisions. This study provides us with a series of decision analysis methodologies when the loss functions of DTRSs are IFNs and extends the range of applications.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: Section 2 provides some basic concepts of Bayesian decision procedure and IFSs. Basic model of IFDTRSs is designed in Section 3. Then, decision analysis of IFDTRSs for single-period decision making and its relevant properties are explored in Section 4. With the above analysis, decision analysis of IFDTRSs for multiperiod decision making is further studied in Section 5. An example is presented to illustrate the application of the novel three-way decisions in Section 6. Section 7 concludes the paper and elaborates on future studies.

div.head: Preliminaries
div.p: Basic concepts, notations and results of Bayesian decision procedure [6,[51][52][53] and IFSs [1,15,40,41,45,47] are briefly reviewed in this section.

div.head: Bayesian decision procedure
div.p: The theoretical framework of DTRSs is Bayesian decision procedure [51,52]. With respect to the results presented in [6],

Bayesian decision procedure is elaborated as follows. The set of states given by X ¼ fw 1 ; w 2 ; . . . ; w m g is a finite set of m states and A ¼ fa 1 ; a 2 ; . . . ; a n g is a finite set of n possible actions. Prðw i jxÞ is the conditional probability of an object x being in state w i given that the object is described by x. Without loss of generality, we simply assume that these conditional probabilities Prðw i jxÞ and PrðxÞ are known. Let kða j jw i Þ denote the loss or cost for taking action a j in the state w i . For an object x, suppose action a j is taken. Since Prðw i jxÞ is the probability of the state w i by given x, the expected loss associated with taking action a j is given below:
div.formula: Rða j jxÞ ¼ X m i¼1 kða j jw i ÞPrðw i jxÞ:ð1Þ
div.p: Given description x of the object x, a decision rule can be conceived as a function sðxÞ that specifies which action to take, and the overall risk R is calculated by: R ¼ X
x

div.head: RðsðxÞjxÞPrðxÞ; ð2Þ
div.p: where the summation is over the set of all possible descriptions of objects. If sðxÞ is chosen so that RðsðxÞjxÞ is as small as possible for every x, the overall risk R is minimum. For every object x, we compute the conditional risk Rða j jxÞ for every action by (1) and select the action for which the conditional risk is minimum. If more than one action minimizes, any tiebreaking rule can be used.

div.head: Intuitionistic fuzzy sets (IFSs)
div.p: The concept of IFSs [1] is an extension of the concept of fuzzy sets [60]. In the following, we review some basic concepts of IFSs and their operations [1,15,[39][40][41]45,47]. Definition 1. Let U be a fixed set. An intuitionistic fuzzy set (IFS) E on U can be represented as the following mathematical symbol:
div.formula: E ¼ f< f ; l E ðf Þ; m E ðf Þ > jf 2 Ug;ð3Þ
div.p: where the functions l E ðf Þ : U ! ½0; 1 and m E ðf Þ : U ! ½0; 1 are the membership degree and non-membership degree of f to E, respectively.
Definition 1 provides a way to evaluate the same problem with the positive and the negative perspectives. In light of Definition 1, the relationship between l E ðf Þ and m E ðf Þ for 8f 2 U is:
div.formula: 0 6 l E ðf Þ þ m E ðf Þ 6 1.
div.p: Meanwhile, the hesitation (or uncertainty) membership of f in U can be calculated as:
div.formula: p E ðf Þ ¼ 1 À l E ðf Þ À m E ðf Þ;ð4Þ
div.p: where the value of p E ðf Þ satisfies 0 6 p E ðf Þ 6 1. If the value of p E ðf Þ is small, then the knowledge of f is more certain and vice versa [3]. According to the notations reported in [39,40], an intuitionistic fuzzy number (IFN) can be denoted as
div.formula: Eðf Þ ¼ ðl E ðf Þ; m E ðf ÞÞ.
div.p: In light of the results presented in [39][40][41]45], we discuss the three-way decisions based on IFNs below.

div.head: Intuitionistic fuzzy decision-theoretic rough set model
div.p: Considering the new uncertainty measurement of IFSs, we discuss the loss function of DTRSs with IFNs in this section. In light of Bayesian decision procedure [20][21][22]51,52], we construct intuitionistic fuzzy decision-theoretic rough sets (IFDTRSs).

The IFDTRS model is composed of two states and three actions. The set of states is given by X ¼ fC; :Cg indicating that an object is in C and not in C, respectively. The set of actions is given by A ¼ fa P ; a B ; a N g, where a P ; a B , and a N represent three actions when classifying object x, namely, deciding x 2 POSðCÞ, deciding x should be further investigated x 2 BNDðCÞ, and deciding x 2 NEGðCÞ, respectively. The intuitionistic fuzzy loss function matrix regarding the risk or cost of actions in the different states is given in Table 1.

In Table 1, E is an intuitionistic fuzzy concept of the loss and the loss functions Eðk Þ are IFNsð ¼ P; B; NÞ. Eðk PP Þ; Eðk BP Þ and Eðk NP Þ denote the loss degrees in the E with IFNs incurred for taking actions of a P ; a B and a N , respectively, when an object belongs to C, e.g., Eðk PP Þ ¼ ð0; 1Þ; Eðk BP Þ ¼ ð0:1; 0:8Þ and Eðk NP Þ ¼ ð0:9; 0Þ. Similarly, Eðk PN Þ; Eðk BN Þ and Eðk NN Þ denote the loss degrees incurred for taking the same actions when the object belongs to :C. By considering a reasonable kind of loss functions with:

div.p: For Proposition 1, (11) and (12) illustrate that the loss of classifying an object x belonging to C into the positive region POSðCÞ is less than the loss of classifying x into the boundary region BNDðCÞ, and both of these losses are strictly less than the loss of classifying x into the negative region NEGðCÞ [21]. The reverse orders of these losses are suitable for classifying an object not in C. It is notable that ( 7)- (10) are the prerequisite of the IFDTRSs. According to ( 19)-( 21), the values of the expected losses (i.e., Rða P j½xÞ; Rða B j½xÞ and Rða N j½xÞ) are determined by the loss functions of Table 1. Propositions 3-5 display the variations of the elements in the expected losses with the increasing of the loss functions. From Example 2, the variations of the elements in the expected losses may be uncertain when one loss associated with the expected loss is increasing and the other is simultaneously decreasing. Hence, we elicit the following proposition. Proposition 6. Under (11), ( 12), the relationships among Rða P j½xÞ; Rða B j½xÞ and Rða N j½xÞ depend on the values of loss functions in Table 1, which are uncertain and need be further compared with each other.

The purpose of DTRSs is to provide some decision rules replied on the Bayesian decision procedure [20][21][22]. Under the intuitionist fuzzy environment, the Bayesian decision procedure suggests the following minimum-cost decision rules: where Rða P j½xÞ; Rða B j½xÞ and Rða N j½xÞ are IFNs. According to the result presented in Proposition 6, the decision rules (P)-(N) need to be further investigated based on ( 19)-( 21) and the operations of IFNs.

div.head: Decision analysis of IFDTRSs for single-period decision making
div.p: As we stated in Section 3, the decision rules (P)-(N) need to be further discussed. From Definition 1, an IFN characterized both by a membership degree and a non-membership degree, provides a way to evaluate the decision problem with the positive and the negative viewpoints [1,5]. Under the limited evaluation information of single-period decision making, we mainly adopt the concepts of IFNs and design three types of strategies to deduce three-way decisions (i.e., Strategies 1-3).

div.head: Strategy 1: A positive viewpoint
div.p: For decision rules (P)-(N), the expected losses Rða P j½xÞ ¼ ðl P ; m P Þ; Rða B j½xÞ ¼ ðl B ; m B Þ and Rða N j½xÞ ¼ ðl N ; m N Þ are IFNs. With regard to the positive viewpoint, we directly use the membership degrees of IFNs to represent the expected losses. When we compare the expected losses, the membership degrees of the expected losses keep in step with them. According to this scenario, decision rules (P)-(N) can be re-expressed as: where l P ¼ 1 À ð1 À l E ðk PP ÞÞ PrðCj½xÞ ð1 À l E ðk PN ÞÞ Prð:Cj½xÞ ; l B ¼ 1 À ð1 À l E ðk BP ÞÞ PrðCj½xÞ ð1 À l E ðk BN ÞÞ Prð:Cj½xÞ and l N ¼ 1À ð1 À l E ðk NP ÞÞ PrðCj½xÞ ð1 À l E ðk NN ÞÞ Prð:Cj½xÞ . div.head: Strategy 3: A composite viewpoint
div.p: With regards to Strategy 1, it merely uses the membership degrees of IFNs to generate decision rules with the positive viewpoint. In the negative viewpoint, Strategy 2 only uses the non-membership degrees of IFNs to deduce decision rules. From Example 3, we find the inconsistency of Strategies 1 and 2. For solving this problem, we need to synchronously consider the membership degrees and the non-membership degrees of IFNs, which is called as a composite viewpoint. In order to compare the expected losses Rða P j½xÞ ¼ ðl P ; m P Þ; Rða B j½xÞ ¼ ðl B ; m B Þ and Rða N j½xÞ ¼ ðl N ; m N Þ, we introduce the score function and the accuracy function of an IFN [3,39].
In light of Definition 2, the score functions of the expected losses can be determined as follows:

div.head: Decision analysis of IFDTRSs for multi-period decision making
div.p: With the above-mentioned decision analysis of Section 4, it focuses on the single-period decision making and all the original decision information are provided at one period. However, the original argument information may be collected from different periods [10,43,44], e.g. climate policy [29], multi-period (multi-stage) investment decision making [43,44]. Take the Shanghai composite index as an example, the trend is described in Fig. 5.

In Fig. 5, it shows the Shanghai composite index of each day from 2013/8/11 to 2014/8/11. When we ascertain the stock investment decision, we not only use the latest data, but also synthetically utilize these historical information. As the results shown in [43,44], every period may have different weight to impact on our decision. To the multi-period decision making issue, it has also attracted the attention of the domain of three-way decisions. For example, Yao and Deng [55] considered the cost of obtaining the necessary evidence for making a classification decision and proposed a sequential three-way decisions by adding one or more attributes each time. Yao [58] further presented a granular computing perspective on sequential three-way decisions. Considering the dynamic change of loss functions presented in DTRSs, Liu et al. [29] proposed a dynamic decision-theoretic rough sets with the time. Hu [10] introduced novel dynamic two-way decisions and dynamic three-way decisions based on three-way decisions spaces and three-way decisions with a pair of evaluation functions. Inspired by these works, we extend the IFDTRSs with single-period decision making to adapt the multi-period situation by using Strategy 3 of Section 4.

div.head: The determination for the aggregation of the loss function at all periods
div.p: With the insightful gain from a dynamic intuitionistic fuzzy weighted averaging (DIFWA) operator presented in [44], we can aggregate the intuitionistic fuzzy loss function matrices at each period by using an integrated intuitionistic fuzzy loss function matrix. With respect to the results presented in Proposition 10 and Example 4, we find the score of loss function with DIFWA is between DIFPA and DIFOA. The reason is DIFWA involves the importance of each period. Meanwhile, DIFPA and DIFOA merely consider some special cases. In order to synthetically utilize the historical information, DIFWA is more suitable for the following decision analysis.

Finally, we design an algorithm to deduce three-way decisions for multi-period decision making as follows:

Step 1: Determine the weight vector w ¼ ðwðt 1 Þ; wðt 2 Þ; . . . ; wðt k Þ; . . . ; wðt q ÞÞ T for q periods, the concept of C in accordance with the decision problem and the conditional probability of the object belonging to C, i.e., PrðCj½xÞ.
Step 2: In light of ( 34)- (37) and Table 4, we collect the loss function information at each period, respectively.

Step 3: Using the operation DIFWA, we calculate the scores and the accuracies of the expected losses based on ( 46)-( 51), i.e., SðRða P j½xÞÞ; SðRða B j½xÞÞ; SðRða N j½xÞÞ; HðRða P j½xÞÞ; HðRða B j½xÞÞ; HðRða N j½xÞÞ.

Step 4: Comparing the scores of the expected losses, we select the expected loss with the minimum score. If the number of the expected loss with the minimum score is equal to 1, the action of x depends on the action with the minimum score, go to Step 7. Otherwise, go to Step 5.

Step 5: For the expected losses with the same minimum score, we continue to compare their accuracies. If the number of the expected loss with the minimum accuracy is equal to 1, the action of x depends on the corresponding action with the minimum accuracy and go to Step 7. Otherwise, go to Step 6.
Step 6: In light of the preference of the decision maker to POSðCÞ; BNDðCÞ and NEGðCÞ, we select the more preference from the actions with the minimum score of expected losses.

Step 7: End. With the above-mentioned algorithm, Step 6 is associated with the preference of the decision maker to POSðCÞ; BNDðCÞ and NEGðCÞ. For example, if the decision maker has a preference order POSðCÞ 1 BNDðCÞ 1 NEGðCÞ, it means that the alternatives classified into POSðCÞ dominate into BNDðCÞ, and the alternatives into both of these regions dominate into NEGðCÞ [21]. If BNDðCÞ and NEGðCÞ simultaneously hold in Step 6, we will finally select the action BNDðCÞ.

div.head: An illustrative example
div.p: In this section, we use three-way decisions with IFDTRSs to support the investment decisions of agroecological regions of Hubei Province and illustrate the decision process of the novel three-way decisions. For the agroecological regions of Hubei Province, Xu [44] With respect to the limited resources, we need to make a choice under the intuitionistic fuzzy environment [44]. On the one hand, we want to rightly allocate resource, especially for the backward area [21]. On the other hand, we also consider that some possible decision results of the selection may result in different losses. Hence, the investment decisions of agroecological regions of Hubei Province are consistent with three-way decisions. According to the decision strategies of three-way decisions, we have the acceptance decision, the rejection decision and the non-commitment decision [20][21][22]30,57]. In order to evaluate these agroecological regions, a committee has been set up to provide assessment information on x i ði ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; 7Þ [44].

For the investment decisions of agroecological regions of Hubei Province, we have two states X ¼ fC; :Cg indicating that the agroecological region is a backward area or not. The set of actions for the new agroecological region x i ði ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; 7Þ is given by A ¼ fa P ; a B ; a N g, where a P ; a B , and a N represent the investment, need for further investigation and not to make an investment, respectively. The committee evaluates the performance of agroecological regions in the years 2004-2006. Let t 1 ; t 2 ; t 3 denote the year ''2004'', the year ''2005'' and the year ''2006'', respectively. There are 3 periods and the corresponding weight vector w ¼ ðwðt 1 Þ; wðt 2 Þ; wðt 3 ÞÞ T is ð0:2; 0:3; 0:5Þ T . Thus, we use the algorithm of decision analysis based on IFDTRSs for multi-period decision making.
Step 1: In this example, we assume that the conditional probability of each alternative region to C is shown in Table 7.
Step 2: The values of the loss functions at the different period are listed in Tables 8910.
Step 3: Based on ( 46)-( 51), we calculate the scores of the expected losses and the accuracies of the expected losses for each region. The results are shown in Fig. 7.

In order to illustrate the calculation procedure, we take the region x 3 as an example. In light of the results presented in Table 7, the conditional probability PrðCj½x 3 Þ is 0.4. Hence, Prð:Cj½x 3 Þ ¼ 0:6. For the region x 3 , the score of Rða P j½x 3 is calculated based on (46)

Similarly, the accuracies of other expected losses are calculated: HðRða B j½x 3 ÞÞ ¼ 0:9404 and HðRða N j½x 3 ÞÞ ¼ 0:8913.

Step 4: According to the results reported in Fig. 7, we find each region has just one minimum score. As the number of the expected loss with the minimum score is equal to 1, the action of each region depends on the action with its minimum score. The decision results of each region are shown in Table 11.

As we state above, the scores of the expected losses of x 3 are calculated: SðRða P j½x 3 ÞÞ ¼ 0:4888; SðRða B j½x 3 ÞÞ ¼ 0:1228 and SðRða N j½x 3 ÞÞ ¼ 0:2030. Following Step 4, we compare the scores of the expected losses and find that SðRða B j½xÞÞ ¼ 0:1228 is minimum. At this point, the number of the expected loss with the minimum score is equal to 1. Hence, we classify the region x 3 into BNDðCÞ and take the non-commitment decision (further investigation), namely, a B . According to the decision results of Table 11, the committee believes that x 1 and x 4 need to be invested immediately, while x 2 and x 7 should not be selected for investment. In addition, the committee also suggest x 3 ; x 5 and x 6 need to be further investigated. In order to validate the effectiveness of IFDTRSs for multi-period decision making, we compare the decision results based on IFDTRSs for single-period decision making in the year 2005. In light of decision rules (P3)-(N3), we directly provide the investment decision of each region in the year 2005. The decision results are shown in Table 12.

From Table 12, the committee believes that x 1 ; x 4 ; x 5 and x 6 need to be invested immediately, while x 2 ; x 3 and x 7 should not be selected for investment. The decision results of x 3 ; x 5 and x 6 in the year 2005 are different from Table 11. The reason is that most of the values of the loss functions in the year 2005 are different from other years. Compared with the results of Table 12, the results of Table 11 synthetically utilize the historical information of three periods.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this paper, we propose a naive model of IFDTRSs based on DTRSs and IFNs. Then, we successively derive three-way decisions from the single period decision making to the multi-period situation. Meanwhile, we elaborate their relevant properties. With respect to the single-period decision making, we design three strategies and obtain their applicabilities. Under the multi-period scenarios, we analyze three aggregation operations of IFDTRSs, i.e., DIFWA, DIFPA and DIFOA. Finally, we determine DIFWA as a suitable aggregation operation for the loss function at all periods and design an algorithm for deriving three-way decisions. This study considers the uncertainty format of IFSs and extends the range of applications of DTRSs. Our future researches will focus on studying generalization models based on the IFDTRSs model.

In the light of the negative viewpoint, we straightly adopt the non-membership degrees of IFNs to analyze decision rules (P)-(N). Under this situation, the non-membership degrees of the expected losses have opposite directions with the expected losses. Following this scenario, decision rules (P)-(N) can be re-expressed as: ðP2Þ If m P P m B and m P P m N ; decide x 2 POSðCÞ; ðB2Þ If m B P m P and m B P m N ; decide x 2 BNDðCÞ; ðN2Þ If m N P m P and m N P m B ; decide x 2 NEGðCÞ; where m m P P m B () ðm E ðk PP ÞÞ PrðCj½xÞ ðm E ðk PN ÞÞ Prð:Cj½xÞ P ðm E ðk BP ÞÞ PrðCj½xÞ ðm E ðk BN ÞÞ Prð:Cj½xÞ () logððm E ðk PP ÞÞ PrðCj½xÞ ðm E ðk PN ÞÞ Prð:Cj½xÞ Þ P logððm E ðk BP ÞÞ PrðCj½xÞ ðm E ðk BN ÞÞ Prð:Cj½xÞ Þ () PrðCj½xÞ logðm E ðk PP ÞÞ þ Prð:Cj½xÞ logðl E ðk PN ÞÞ P PrðCj½xÞ logðm E ðk BP ÞÞ þ Prð:Cj½xÞ logðm E ðk BN ÞÞ () PrðCj½xÞ P log

For the rule ðPÞ, the first condition Rða P j½xÞ 6 Rða B j½xÞ based on Definition 3 implies the following prerequisites: (C1) SðRða P j½xÞÞ < SðRða B j½xÞÞ or (C2) SðRða P j½xÞÞ ¼ SðRða B j½xÞÞ ^HðRða P j½xÞÞ 6 HðRða B j½xÞÞ. In the same way, the prerequisites for the second condition Rða P j½xÞ 6 Rða N j½xÞ of rule ðPÞ are: (C3) SðRða P j½xÞÞ < SðRða N j½xÞÞ or (C4) SðRða P j½xÞÞ ¼ SðRða N j½xÞÞ ^HðRða P j½xÞÞ 6 HðRða N j½xÞÞ. The first condition of rule ðBÞ is the converse of the first condition of rule ðPÞ. Its prerequisites are: (C5) SðRða B j½xÞÞ < SðRða P j½xÞÞ or (C6) SðRða B j½xÞÞ ¼ SðRða P j½xÞÞ ^HðRða B j½xÞÞ 6 HðRða P j½xÞÞ. For the second condition of rule ðBÞ, we have: (C7) SðRða B j½xÞÞ < SðRða N j½xÞÞ or (C8) SðRða B j½xÞÞ ¼ SðRða N j½xÞÞ ^HðRða B j½xÞÞ 6 HðRða N j½xÞÞ. The first condition of rule ðNÞ is the converse of the second condition of rule ðPÞ and the second condition of rule ðNÞ is the converse of the second condition of rule ðBÞ. For Rða N j½xÞ 6 Rða P j½xÞ, its prerequisites are:
